intro: Roupala subintegerrima, commonly known as the Chilean rosewood, is a small evergreen tree native to southern Chile. It belongs to the family Proteaceae and is characterized by its smooth, dark bark and glossy, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, white, fragrant flowers that bloom in spring, followed by woody, spherical pods containing seeds. It thrives in temperate climates and is often found in coastal and mountainous regions. Due to its ornamental value and historical use in woodworking, it is a species of interest in both horticulture and conservation efforts.
